## PHYSICS

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 386, 403]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 411, 719, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. Write in dark blue or black pen. You may use a pencil for any diagrams, graphs or rough working. Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid. DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 494, 254, 510]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 520, 760, 552]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 561, 91]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 279, 920, 330]]<|/det|>

Record the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{h}}\) of this water, as shown on the thermometer. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[175, 214, 823, 255]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 273, 534, 293]]<|/det|> [b] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 335, 146, 353]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 335, 920, 415]]<|/det|> She adds \(10 \text{cm}^3\) of the cold water to the beaker of hot water. She quickly repeats this five times, adding \(10 \text{cm}^3\) of cold water each time, until a total of \(60 \text{cm}^3\) has been added. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 719, 92]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 825, 920, 861]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 866, 181, 884]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 865, 697, 884]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 880, 920, 900]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 816, 89]]<|/det|> Fig. 4.2 shows the mirror which is made of polished metal and has a vertical line <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 87, 472, 106]]<|/det|> The lower end of this line is at point \(\mathbf{N}\). <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[272, 116, 724, 217]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 233, 534, 252]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 265, 920, 330]]<|/det|> In the experiment, the student places a pin \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) at \(\mathbf{C}\). The student views the line on the mirror and the image of pin \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) from the direction indicated by the eye in Fig. 4.1. She places two pins \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) some distance apart so that the image of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\), the line on the mirror, and pins \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\), all appear exactly one behind the other. The positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) are shown. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 342, 180, 359]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 342, 920, 375]]<|/det|> Draw the line joining the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\). Continue the line until it meets the normal. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 381, 180, 400]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 381, 532, 400]]<|/det|> Draw the line joining point \(\mathbf{C}\) and point \(\mathbf{N}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 396, 920, 415]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 421, 181, 440]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 421, 920, 471]]<|/det|> Measure, and record in Table 4.1, the angle of incidence \(i\) between the normal \(\mathbf{NL}\) and the line \(\mathbf{CN}\). Measure, and record in the table, the angle of reflection \(r\) between the normal and the line passing through \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 478, 180, 496]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 477, 554, 496]]<|/det|> Complete the column headings in the table. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 508, 539, 526]]<|/det|> Table 4.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[268, 540, 730, 653]]<|/det|>
